reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s sailing-to-an-island metaphor, claiming it misleads by implying a static target and conditions. That metaphor is mainly an introductory framing device; the core argument for “no easy eutopia” rests on substantive claims about moral fragility/multiplicativity, population ethics, digital beings, bounded vs unbounded value functions, etc. So centrality is low. The point has some bite insofar as the metaphor could under-describe path-dependence and endogenous values, but the essay itself flags complexity and only uses the metaphor to separate three difficulty components, so refuting the metaphor weakens little of the actual case (modest strength). The critique’s main descriptive claim (static geographic analogies miss evolving values/feedback) is largely true, though the label “reference class failure” is not quite apt and the inference to undermining “the paper’s framing” is somewhat overstated. It is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Static navigation metaphor fails to capture evolving values and feedback loops
